DOC.HEAD: Report: Noriega Was Working on Personal History
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had begun work on his memoirs and met with a New York lawyer to discuss publishing rights the day U.S. forces invaded Panama, a newspaper reported today. The Panamanian strongman knew at the time of the Tuesday meeting that a U.S. invasion was imminent, a member of the law firm told New York Newsday. Noriega had gathered material, including details of his work for U.S. intelligence and his rise to power through the Panamanian military, said attorney Barry Slotnick. ``He realized his time was very short in terms of his ability to maintain himself in Panama,'' Slotnick said. The firm Slotnick and Baker has held extensive talks with Noriega about the U.S. indictments against him on drug trafficking charges, Slotnick said. He said Noriega met a member of the firm Tuesday in Panama City to discuss publishing arrangements. Noriega said a ``substantial portion'' of the manuscript had been finished. ``He knew the Justice Department wanted him on trial; he was aware the United States was going to invade; he felt they wanted to kill or capture him,'' said Slotnick, adding Noriega appeared calm during the meeting. U.S. forces invaded Panama at midnight Tuesday. A publisher hasn't been found and a price hadn't been discussed, Slotnick said. He said Noriega refused to approach a publisher in the United States, or permit a U.S. company to base a movie or television drama on it.
